Award.AwardTitle: Effects of host-use traits on RNA virus evolvability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Whereas some viruses can easily shift to infect new host populations, other viruses remain confined to their original host. This research examines the environmental factors that cause viruses to be specialists that infect few hosts or generalists that attack a variety of hosts. This goal is accomplished using experimental evolution of Vesicular Stomatitis Virus in laboratory culture. The first major objective is to determine how virus traits evolve when viruses adapt to using single versus multiple hosts, especially whether evolution is constrained such that some traits must be modified by natural selection before others can undergo change. The second major objective is to determine whether specialist and generalist viruses differ in their probability of evolving to emerge on new hosts such as humans, and whether adaptations specifically for surviving outside of hosts alter the likelihood of successfully infecting new hosts.

The project results can be applied to several systems because viruses are important disease agents in wild and domesticated populations of animals and plants. The project virus resembles many vector-borne human viruses (such as West Nile Fever Virus); thus, the project should help elucidate environmental factors promoting viral host shifts into human populations. The project will involve the training of undergraduate students and outreach to the New Haven Public Schools with a particular focus on recruiting and mentoring minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merits of this project concerned increased understanding of how changing environments impact virus evolution. All organisms occasionally face environmental change, but viruses are especially vulnerable to changes in the resources (hosts) they encounter, changes in abiotic stressors (temperatures), and changes in host defense systems (immunity). However, viruses are among the most successful entities on the planet, judging by their numerical prevalence in the biosphere. The intellectual merits of the project focused on rigorous lab studies that measured how virus genetics, genomics, and traits evolved in response to environmental perturbations. In this way, we improved understanding of how viruses continuously face envronmental changes, and yet remain biologically successful. 

The broader impacts of the project involved a wide variety of outreach and educational efforts that sought to distill these findings to the lay public. During the award period, very many presentations occurred at public schools, museums, university and college classrooms, and even at restaurants that hosted "meet the scientist" events. Also, the broader impacts included seminar courses for public school teachers in the Yale National Initiative, where faculty help teachers develop new curriculum units which will enrich the classroom experiences for their students at very many locations around the USA. Because this program focuses on under-served children, it is extremely effective at improving education in the most needy classrooms. Last, the project offered abundant training opportunities for undergraduates, grad students and postdocs who were directly involved in the research.
